name: Interviewer
line: MASS EXTINCTION.

name: Tyson
line: Hello, I'm Neil deGrasse Tyson, your host for NOVA scienceNOW.

name: Tyson
line: We all know that Earth is brimming with life, all kinds of life, as it has been for most of the last 600 million years. But every now and then, something happens. Earth becomes a very unfriendly place, and most life can't survive. It's called mass extinction. We know it's happened over and over again, in the deep past, but we don't always know why.

name: Tyson
line: In a remote Nevada desert, a team of investigators is trying to solve an old murder mystery.

name: Interviewer
line: So yeah, this looks good.

name: Tyson
line: And I mean old; the victims were knocked off about 250 million years ago, in an ancient mass extinction.

name: Interviewer
line: Based on the fossil record, this is probably the most profound extinction of animal life.

name: Interviewer
line: There's no other time, in the last 600 million years, that you wipe out 95 percent of all the species in the ocean.

name: Tyson
line: Geologist Sam Bowring and paleontologist Doug Erwin think this hillside might be a scene of the crime. They're looking for clues to find out what caused the mysterious end of the geological time period known as the Permian.

name: Interviewer
line: The Permian world, and the extinction that ended the Permian world, really reset the nature of life on this planet.

name: Tyson
line: Paleontologist Peter Ward has spent years collecting fossils from the strange time of the Permian.

name: Interviewer
line: Permian would have looked very different to us. Let's say we go back there, we look around

name: Tyson
line: True mammals hadn't evolved yet, but their ancestors were there, animals like this Lemurosaurus.

name: Interviewer
line: This is a mammal-like reptile, probably small-dog size. This animal is a carnivore. It really has a dog-like appearance. We can see this great big piercing tooth.

name: Tyson
line: Clearly making him a predator.

name: Interviewer
line: Yeah, but this entire group dies out in the extinction itself.

name: Tyson
line: There were creatures right out of a science fiction movie, like plant-eating Lystrosaurs, and, ruining their day, monstrous Gorgons.

name: Tyson
line: The extinction ravaged the oceans, once filled with exotic animals. But then, about 250 million years ago, almost everything on sea and land died. So, who's the culprit? What could kill off so much life? Could it be climate change? Global warming? Or would you need something from out of this world?

name: Tyson
line: There've been at least five major extinctions in the last 600 million years. Most of us have heard of one, at the close of the Cretaceous, ending of the reign of the dinosaurs. That happened about 65 million years ago, when an asteroid the size of Mount Everest slammed into our planet, leaving a giant crater near what is now Mexico.

name: Tyson
line: So we know the dinosaurs were knocked off by a giant rock that fell from the sky; and we also know that these rocks hit Earth from time to time; so when we try to figure out what caused all the mass extinctions of the past, shouldn't it just make sense that they'd also be caused by comets and asteroids?

name: Interviewer
line: I went into this controversy fully expecting to find all the evidence for impact. And at the end of the Cretaceous, we see this. We see lots of comet material or asteroid material.

name: Tyson
line: Not to mention the crater, of course.

name: Interviewer
line: Not to mention the crater, least of all the crater.

name: Tyson
line: So you've got the smoking gun, the gun, and the bullets, and, of course, the dead bodies, I guess.

name: Interviewer
line: Well, the only thing we have at the end of the Permian is...are the dead bodies.

name: Tyson
line: So, if asteroids and extinction don't necessarily go hand in hand, what does Earth do with all those asteroids that come our way?

name: Interviewer
line: The Earth is hit by asteroids all the time, big ones, doesn't cause mass extinction. Why not look for something a little bit different?

name: Tyson
line: But where can we find that something?

name: Interviewer
line: Here's the boundary, right here.

name: Tyson
line: This Nevada hillside might be one of a few existing Permian crime scenes in North America, but the team must date the rocks, to see if they're the same age as the extinction.

name: Interviewer
line: Timing is everything. You have to have rocks that can be dated precisely.

name: Tyson
line: Back at the lab, the team breaks down the rock. Rare elements reveal when the rock formed. The results? About 250 million years old.

name: Tyson
line: So this is a crime scene. But where's the killer? What kind of a disaster, other than an asteroid, could destroy so much life?

name: Tyson
line: One of the prime suspects is an ancient group of volcanoes, now dormant, whose remains lie in eastern Russia. Known as the Siberian Traps, these were no ordinary volcanoes.

name: Interviewer
line: Most people, when they think of volcanoes, think of Mount St. Helens or Mount Pinatubo. That's nothing like these volcanic episodes.

name: Tyson
line: The Siberian Traps oozed lava for up to a million years, smothering an area about the size of the continental United States, in some places, over a mile deep.

name: Interviewer
line: That is a lot of lava.

name: Tyson
line: Sure is. But still, the lava was in Siberia, not in the rest of the world, not in the whole ocean. So why would almost everything on Earth die?

name: Tyson
line: Marine geochemist Lee Kump thinks he's found the answer. The key is in how big volcanoes could change the environment, including the chemistry of the Permian ocean.

name: Tyson
line: To test his idea, he designed a computer model to simulate the Permian world.

name: Interviewer
line: So the model starts out like a weather forecasting model or a climate model

name: Tyson
line: All plants and animals and bacteria are, in fact, chemical factories, taking in nutrients and spewing out waste products. With life's chemistry factored in, Lee's model reveals a disturbing chain of events.

name: Tyson
line: It all starts with the Siberian Traps, but the trigger is not the incessant flow of lava, which would burn and bury any life nearby. No, the real culprits are the gases that the volcanoes spew into the atmosphere, including one we've all heard of lately, carbon dioxide.

name: Interviewer
line: Carbon dioxide that's spewing out of these volcanoes is a greenhouse gas.

name: Tyson
line: Greenhouse gases trap the Sun's heat in our atmosphere, forcing the whole Earth to warm up. Of course, that's global warming. But it doesn't end there. Global warming would have heated the Permian ocean, and when it did, ocean chemistry would have changed dramatically.

name: Interviewer
line: There's a difference between warm and cold water. Cold water can hold more gas than can warm water. And so this is, fundamentally, why we drink champagne and beer and soda cold, rather than warm.

name: Tyson
line: What's true for champagne, beer or soda is also true for the ocean and one of its most important gases, oxygen.

name: Interviewer
line: Cold water can hold a lot of oxygen. Warm water can't hold much oxygen.

name: Tyson
line: And if water loses its oxygen, things can go from bad to worse.

name: Tyson
line: Lee and his research team have seen this firsthand, at Green Lakes in central New York State. This lake is narrow and deep, and there's little wind. As a result, the deeper waters have lost their oxygen.

name: Interviewer
line: It's safe to swim in this lake, as long as you stay above 70 feet.

name: Tyson
line: Below that, the oxygen-free water has attracted a deadly form of bacteria.

name: Interviewer
line: There are bacteria that can thrive under those conditions, and those bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide. Hydrogen sulfide is a very toxic substance, and so, the deep part of this lake is highly poisonous.

name: Tyson
line: It's also bright pink.

name: Interviewer
line: Here you go.

name: Interviewer
line: When we bring these samples to the surface, of course, they're rich in hydrogen sulfide. They stink like rotten eggs, and they're poisonous.

name: Interviewer
line: Oh, that stinks! Yuck.

name: Tyson
line: The bright pink color comes from another microbe, purple sulfur bacteria, that thrive in hydrogen sulfide. Bacteria like these can leave chemical traces in ancient rocks. In fact, such traces have been found in some rocks dating to the Permian extinction.

name: Tyson
line: For Lee, it's a sign that the Permian ocean might have resembled this poisonous lake.

name: Interviewer
line: This lake is a microcosm of what we think the ocean was like in the late Permian.

name: Tyson
line: According to Lee's computer model, over time, the oceans would have become so full of hydrogen sulfide that in some spots, the deadly gas would have bubbled right out into the atmosphere, killing millions of creatures, not only in the sea, but also on the land.

name: Tyson
line: The deadly microbes under suspicion aren't rare. They thrive wherever there's water and no oxygen, as Peter Ward showed me, on an ordinary beach, at low tide.

name: Interviewer
line: Even here, we're on a beach in Seattle, we only have to go down about two inches to see, sort of, the next step, in what we think is this extinction mechanism. There. Smell that.

name: Tyson
line: Ooh, yeah, smells like rotten eggs.

name: Interviewer
line: Rotten eggs. So, this is hydrogen sulfide from bacteria in the sediment. So, let's just take those bacteria, put them in the ocean and have untold tons of them.

name: Tyson
line: Having...have it run amok.

name: Interviewer
line: Everywhere. The oceans are bacteria filled. And they're producing that same nasty rotten-egg smell, but in sufficient quantity, not just to kill stuff in the water, but enough goes in the atmosphere to kill land life.

name: Tyson
line: So it burps up this noxious gas.

name: Interviewer
line: Big bubbles come out of the oceans, and it will kill off animals and plants.

name: Tyson
line: And so, an extinction that began in the ocean works its way to the land.

name: Interviewer
line: Exactly. It's horrible.

name: Tyson
line: So it starts with volcanoes spewing carbon dioxide; next step

name: Tyson
line: Peter Ward is convinced this was the scenario, not just for the Permian, but for most of the other big extinction events, too.

name: Interviewer
line: What really looks like a universal way that this has happened is this global warming, leading to this terrible gas chamber atmosphere killing off life in the ocean and land. It's not so much stuff from space that gets you; it's your own planet.

name: Tyson
line: The Nevada rocks offer some support for the idea, at least for the Permian. This whole area was once at the bottom of an ocean, and tests on the rocks have revealed that, in the years leading up to the extinction, the deep ocean water here had lost its oxygen.

name: Tyson
line: The next step will be to probe these rocks for telltale signs of that nasty bacteria and hydrogen sulfide.

name: Tyson
line: Until there's more evidence, the detectives won't all agree that the case is closed. But these experts are convinced that Earth's own environment could be the perpetrator of a mass extinction, whether it's 250 million years ago or right now.

name: Interviewer
line: We know, for a fact, that there have been huge changes in the environment, in climate change. That could happen again today, no asteroids required. The Earth is an incredibly dynamic place, lots happening. We have to understand those changes if we want to survive.

name: Tyson
line: With winter come fears of the flu, and sometimes the flu can be deadly, especially the bird flu. You've all heard of it. It's a virus that people catch from birds like chickens. It's already killed hundreds of people.

name: Tyson
line: Fortunately, this bird flu does not spread easily from person to person, but if it evolves a way to do that, we could be in big trouble.

name: Tyson
line: Correspondent Chad Cohen met up with folks who are trying to stop that from happening by taking a closer look into our past, at the most deadly viral outbreak ever.

name: Interviewer
line: Whatever scary things are lurking in the back of your freezer, I'll venture a guess you've got nothing on Terrence Tumpey. Getting into his deep freeze, at the CDC in Atlanta, is like prepping for a spacewalk.

name: Interviewer
line: Frozen inside, sits a tiny vial of what might be the deadliest pathogen in history, a virus that hadn't been seen in almost 90 years, the 1918 flu, until Tumpey brought it back from the dead.

name: Interviewer
line: 1918 was the worst pandemic we've seen for any virus, and this killed, probably, at least 50 million people worldwide.

name: Interviewer
line: In 1918, flu took three times as many lives as all of World War I.

name: Interviewer
line: So the question is, Why was it, in 1918, so different? Why did it cause so many excess deaths, compared to other pandemics?

name: Interviewer
line: And could a flu that deadly strike again?

name: Interviewer
line: in the digestive tracts of birds.

name: Interviewer
line: They just happily co-exist there, not causing disease, for the most part, in wild birds.

name: Interviewer
line: But every once in a while, an ordinary bird flu changes.

name: Interviewer
line: It's a mistake in nature. These viruses actually get out and infect other hosts.

name: Interviewer
line: Hosts, like people. That's what scientists think may have happened in 1918.

name: Interviewer
line: The thought was that, in 1918, the virus did cross the species barrier and directly infect humans.

name: Interviewer
line: That's one theory, at least. And when a virus that begins in birds gains the ability to pass from human to human, infecting our lungs, spreading through coughs and sneezes, no one's immune because it's never been around before. And that's when a pandemic occurs.

name: Interviewer
line: We're hearing a lot, recently, about the threat of a new pandemic, the avian flu. It's quite lethal, transmitted through close contact with birds, to people who work and live near birds.

name: Interviewer
line: Fortunately this virus has not figured out how to efficiently transmit itself from human to human.

name: Interviewer
line: Infected people, in other words, cannot infect other people.

name: Interviewer
line: The question is will they ever be able to? And if so, how? And when this virus does strike, why does it kill?

name: Interviewer
line: Terrence Tumpey believes he can find the answers by experimenting with a flu that transmitted and killed very well, the 1918 virus.

name: Interviewer
line: By having this in hand, we can actually try to understand better how these pandemic flu viruses work.

name: Interviewer
line: There was just one small problem

name: Interviewer
line: No one had ever been able to study the 1918 virus, this horrible killer virus, because there were no isolates.

name: Interviewer
line: No living samples. But biologist Jeffrey Taubenberger, searching through preserved tissue samples of World War I soldiers, was able to recover the 1918 flu's genetic code. Somewhere, buried within, are instructions that gave it the ability to kill. But where?

name: Interviewer
line: Unfortunately, when you look at the genetic sequence, the blueprint of this virus, there's no smoking gun that tells us that this particular virus is lethal.

name: Interviewer
line: Tumpey couldn't find an answer by simply reading a recipe for the 1918 flu virus, he needed to experiment with the real thing.

name: Interviewer
line: We felt like it was important to actually reconstruct this virus.

name: Interviewer
line: That's right, he said, reconstruct, rebuild the 1918 flu from scratch, one of the most lethal viruses we've ever known.

name: Interviewer
line: Using Taubenberger's recipe and a technique called reverse genetics, scientists at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine added all the chemical building blocks in the right order and the right amounts, and it worked.

name: Interviewer
line: They created a living 1918 virus so nasty that when Tumpey exposed lab mice to it, they were all dead in just three days.

name: Interviewer
line: I was quite surprised. I didn't anticipate that they would die that quickly. That was very quick.

name: Interviewer
line: And it was just what happened to humans in 1918. Unlike normal flu strains, which can only infect high in the respiratory tract, the 1918 virus attacked tissue deep in the lungs, as well, and that's a vulnerable spot.

name: Interviewer
line: ...the delicate areas of our lung tissues, causing this extreme inflammation, resulting in death.

name: Interviewer
line: The 1918 flu so badly inflamed those areas of its victims' lungs that many died through suffocation. And, as it happens, that's just how the avian flu kills, too.

name: Interviewer
line: Those are important characteristics and similarities among the 1918 virus as well as the avian virus.

name: Interviewer
line: So, these two deadly viruses attack similar parts of the lungs, but that still doesn't answer the biggest question

name: Interviewer
line: Well, first, let's back up a little bit. How does flu infect us in the first place?

name: Interviewer
line: So this is what flu looks like under a microscope?

name: Interviewer
line: Electron microscope, yeah.

name: Interviewer
line: An actual flu virus, but for our purposes, let's represent a virus by this unpleasant fellow.

name: Interviewer
line: For all his nastiness, he isn't all that complex. In fact, he only has eight genes. We, by comparison, have more than 20,000.

name: Interviewer
line: one, because it's responsible for getting the virus into a cell, and the other, for getting it out again.

name: Interviewer
line: Flu gets into cells with the hemagglutinin gene.

name: Interviewer
line: So, in order to penetrate cells, you could imagine that the hemagglutinin was sort of like a key.

name: Interviewer
line: A key, which we'll refer to simply as H. And that key unlocks the cell, so that the virus can get inside.

name: Interviewer
line: If it gets into your cell, it will take over the machinery of the cell and start making more copies of itself.

name: Interviewer
line: But now the virus has a problem. These copies are stuck to that cell. That's where the other gene comes in. It's called Neuraminidase, or N, for short.

name: Interviewer
line: Neuraminidase is critical for release.

name: Interviewer
line: Getting back out?

name: Interviewer
line: Getting back out.

name: Interviewer
line: The virus copies use N to cut themselves free. And now each of them, armed with their own Hs and Ns, are off to infect more cells.

name: Interviewer
line: In birds, there are 16 different kinds of H genes and nine N genes. Every flu is some combination of these. Humans have only caught a few.

name: Interviewer
line: H5N1.

name: Interviewer
line: The avian flu's H key, or hemagglutinin gene, can open the lock between birds and people, that is, transmit from birds to humans. But it still cannot open the lock between people and spread from one person to another, yet.

name: Interviewer
line: once it's in our bodies, the hemagglutinin gene can change. It's as if it can fit the lock, but it can't turn it, which would be great, if it stayed that way. But a virus's genetic recipe constantly changes, or mutates, as scientists like to say. And if just the right changes take place in the hemagglutinin gene, those changes could open the lock, allowing it to spread between people.

name: Interviewer
line: But exactly what are those changes?

name: Interviewer
line: Going back to Taubenberger's recipe for the 1918 virus, Ian Wilson and his colleagues at the Scripps Research Institute found the answer to what the 1918 virus may have needed to spread between humans. They pinpointed two changes, or mutations.

name: Interviewer
line: Only two mutations were sufficient to change the virus's hemagglutinin to adapt to human receptors.

name: Interviewer
line: So could those same two mutations in the avian flu's hemagglutinin gene allow it to spread between humans also?

name: Interviewer
line: To find out, they tried those same two mutations.

name: Interviewer
line: To our surprise, we found that, in fact, we couldn't very easily change it with the mutations that occurred in 1918. So that suggests that it might actually be a little bit more difficult, and it might take a little bit more time, for an H5N1 virus to be able to adapt to human lung cells.

name: Interviewer
line: And that's good news. The Scripps team believes the H5N1, or avian, flu doesn't seem to adapt easily, so that people can infect other people.

name: Interviewer
line: Back at the CDC, Tumpey is taking a different approach to find out why these viruses are so deadly. Instead of experimenting with tiny variations in a flu gene, Tumpey is testing entire genes. He's looking at each of the 1918 virus's eight genes, one by one by one, to see which ones caused it to be so lethal and which ones should be the target of new antiviral drugs. He started with that H key gene.

name: Interviewer
line: He took one from his 1918 virus and put it in an ordinary seasonal flu.

name: Interviewer
line: ...a contemporary influenza strain that doesn't kill, and, all of a sudden, it was lethal.

name: Interviewer
line: And when he did the reverse, took the H key from an ordinary flu and put it on a 1918 virus...

name: Interviewer
line: The virus was no longer lethal; it didn't cause disease.

name: Interviewer
line: So all signs seem to point to the H key, or H.A., as scientists call it, as being, at least partly, responsible for lethality.

name: Interviewer
line: Well, there's something very intriguing about the H.A.

name: Interviewer
line: So intriguing that, now, Tumpey is planning to do something pretty radical

name: Interviewer
line: You want to combine H1, 1918, with H5? What's going on there?

name: Interviewer
line: I think it will be important, as a set of experiments to understand how H5N1 works. And by mix-and-matching it with genes from a virus that actually did that quite well, the 1918 virus, we are hopeful that we can figure that out.

name: Interviewer
line: I think, from a scientific point of view, this is the only way to understand how these pandemic viruses work.

name: Interviewer
line: Tumpey is one of the few people in the world who has the clearance to work with a live 1918 flu virus.

name: Interviewer
line: So if we can figure out how to slow it down, studying this virus as a model virus, then perhaps we'll advance our knowledge on the avian H5N1 virus as well. Maybe we can figure out how to stop it.

name: Interviewer
line: If Terrence Tumpey has his way, the virus that took so many lives in the past may help prevent another from taking more lives in the future.

They'd be able to just interact with a robot the way that they would want to, which we think will be as people interact with other living things.

line: When we first thought about Cog, we thought about the all-intelligent robot that was going to be able to manipulate the world and do things. We weren't thinking about how it was really going to interact with people.

name: Interviewer
line: PAPYRUS.

name: Tyson
line: When I was a kid, I used to play this game, Password(TM). And the secret password is always invisible, hidden until you slid the paper into this sleeve, and then the secret word is revealed.

name: Tyson
line: Well, what if the secret words aren't part of a kids' board game, but instead are on a crumbling, ancient manuscript?

name: Tyson
line: Correspondent Beth Nissen caught up with investigators who are uncovering secret messages that have stayed hidden for 2,000 years.

name: Interviewer
line: In these vaults, on these shelves, in these boxes at Oxford University, ancient clues, 2,000 years old, to a glorious human past; wrapped in printed paper, fragments of ancient paper, pieces of the D.N.A. of Western Civilization.

name: Interviewer
line: Here's one that contains a large page of Homer's Odyssey, still with quite a bit of mud and sand clinging to it.

name: Interviewer
line: These are only a few of the faded fragments found buried near the outskirts of what was, at around the turn from B.C. into A.D., a mid-sized capital city in Greek-ruled Egypt, the city of Oxyrhynchus, actually, found buried in the Oxyrhynchus city dump, in rubbish mounds.

name: Interviewer
line: There can be more Homer, new pieces of Sophocles, Euripides, other authors who were being read in antiquity. You never really know what's going to come out of the box.

name: Interviewer
line: Or whether what comes out of the box can be read.

name: Interviewer
line: Abrasion, dirt, clay, silt

name: Interviewer
line: Yet somehow, buried above the water tables and beneath the dry sands of Egypt, for all those centuries, almost half a million of these papyri fragments survived, these pieces of ancient paper made from papyrus.

name: Interviewer
line: Papyrus is a plant. It is a reed that grows almost exclusively along the banks of the Nile. You shave the stalk into thin strips, lay them parallel to each other, lay strips running perpendicular to them; you pound it or press it, such that the cell walls break down. Cellulose seeps out, creating a kind of gooey natural glue that binds the strips together, which can then be pressed, polished and written on. The stuff is really quite durable, in a way, more durable than the paper you're used to taking notes on today.

name: Interviewer
line: The tons of this reedy paper found at Oxyrhynchus documented the daily life of an ancient city's markets and businesses and courts.

name: Interviewer
line: We have marriage contracts, divorce contracts, tax declarations, census registers, hate mail, dinner invitations. We have letters-home-to-Mom. You name it, we have it on papyrus.

name: Interviewer
line: Thousands more of the Oxyrhynchus fragments were unreadable, soiled, grimy.

name: Interviewer
line: Because this was a rubbish dump, things get charred, if burning waste was put on top of them , or stained.

name: Interviewer
line: Or, like this fragment, which looks, at first, like the work of, say, Jackson Pollack of Crete. The only readable word of Greek is just visible at the very bottom. You can read Christos.

name: Interviewer
line: Yeah, there's Christos, kind of a row sigma with a bar above it. So that's the abbreviation for Christos, you know it's a Christian text. But much of it is totally illegible.

name: Interviewer
line: And papyrologists assume there are letters there. Papyrus was too expensive to throw away unused and often had writing on both sides. But texts like this were a tantalizing, frustrating mystery.

name: Interviewer
line: Really, you're never going to be able to publish a text like this. You can look at that under the microscope as much as you like, but it's just a complete mess.

name: Interviewer
line: What papyrologists really needed was this, an equivalent to Superman's x-ray vision, a way to see through whatever was on the surface of papyri, ancient food stains, burn marks, mummy paint, see through to the writing underneath.

name: Interviewer
line: Eureka!

name: Interviewer
line: It's called multispectral imaging, a technology developed by NASA to see through clouds of gas in space.

name: Interviewer
line: It was a significant step forward, when a scholar at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory decided to apply the technology to texts.

name: Interviewer
line: Ancient texts, written on papyri.

name: Interviewer
line: see if multispectral imaging can help scholars at the University of California at Berkeley read part of an account of the Trojan War, by the poet Dictys of Crete, a part obscured by a large reddish stain.

name: Interviewer
line: Some people think it's a spill, a chemical spill perhaps, or a spot of wine that was dropped on it. Even the best papyrologists who've worked on this are usually not able to pick out any more than a few scattered letters in here, and even at that, they feel like they're guessing.

name: Interviewer
line: The fragile fragment is put on a moving imaging bed under a scientific-grade digital camera, which captures high-definition images of the fragment, through a succession of color filters, one filter at a time, a dozen different filters in all.

name: Interviewer
line: Each individual filter allows only a certain portion of the light spectrum through.

name: Interviewer
line: The light in the range of the spectrum visible to the naked eye, reflects off whatever is on the surface of most of the papyri pieces, the stains, dirt, mummy paint, whatever. The camera can't see much more through these filters than the eye can, which isn't much.

name: Interviewer
line: But results tend to be better, using the filters that let in the range of the light spectrum the human eye cannot see.

name: Interviewer
line: I've seen the best results in the infrared at 950 nanometers.

name: Interviewer
line: Light in the infrared part of the spectrum, invisible to the naked eye but not the camera, is more likely to pass through what's on the papyrus surface to the ink underneath. Surface stains and dirt fade away. The inked letters appear; black magic.

name: Interviewer
line: Ink, which is pretty much pure carbon, it's made out of soot mixed with glue, will absorb all of the infrared, and so it will come out black.

name: Interviewer
line: Every time they see this 21st century technology work on first or second century fragments, papyrologists are thrilled, or as thrilled as papyrologists get.

name: Interviewer
line: None of us is really inclined to give high-fives and celebrate too much, but we were really pleased.

name: Interviewer
line: They've been pleased with multispectral imaging at Oxford, too, home of the world's largest collection of ancient papyri

name: Interviewer
line: They have as many as 500,000 fragments, but only about one percent have been read and published by the few scholars working on them. Uncounted thousands are illegible, in shreds, soiled.

name: Interviewer
line: There are fragments there that we'd pretty much completely given up all hope of ever being able to read.

name: Interviewer
line: Like that Jackson Pollack-y fragment that had the word Christos on it.

name: Interviewer
line: We put it under the multispectral imaging camera, and, all of a sudden, the background completely drops out, and wherever there was ink, you can read the ink as clear as the day it was written.

name: Interviewer
line: And what was written? A passage from the New Testament, St. Paul's Epistle to the Romans, Chapter 14, Verses 7-9.

name: Interviewer
line: And then Eis touto gar Christos apethanen, for this reason did Christ die. And it is now our earliest copy for these verses. We did have another third century papyrus of the Epistle to the Romans, but it actually is very fragmentary. But now, we've got a complete text of these verses in a late second and early third, perhaps, century copy.

name: Interviewer
line: I don't know how long we have, until the things sitting in shoeboxes in this or that university turn to dust, but we've got to get rolling. There are a great many, I mean, many thousands of papyri that are sitting in boxes in dark hallways, waiting to be read.

name: Tyson
line: And now for some final thoughts on extinction. When you look up to the sky, you see the Moon, Sun and stars, not as they are, but as they once were. Traveling at more than 186,000 miles per second, their light simply takes time to reach us.

name: Tyson
line: From the Moon, it takes between one and two seconds; from the Sun, a little more than eight minutes; from Alpha Centauri, the nearest star system to the Sun, about four years; from the Andromeda Galaxy, a close neighbor of the Milky Way, light takes more than two million years to reach us.

name: Tyson
line: So the farther away an object is, the further back in time we see it. Keep this up, and eventually, we bear witness to the birth of galaxies and the birth of the universe itself.

name: Tyson
line: Yes, we can look into the past of distant places, but aliens within those distant places can look our way, and bear witness to our distant past. For all we know, light from Earth's greatest extinction episode is just now reaching alien telescopes, perhaps prompting them to wonder, Has Planet Earth reached a dead end? Does life there have any future at all? Today, with the highest rate of species going extinct since the demise of the dinosaurs, those same questions should perhaps occur to us, too. And that is the cosmic perspective.
